  • save (str) – directory where to save raw data as csv
Returns:

amodata as pandas dataframe
Return type:

pandas dataframe

class ecoop.cf.cfPlot[source]¶
expanding_smoother(data, stype='rolling_mean', min_periods=None, freq=None)[source]¶

Perform a expanding smooting on the data for a complete help refer to http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/dev/computation.html

Parameters:
  • data – pandas dataframe input data
  • stype – soothing type
  • min_periods – periods
  • freq – frequence

smoothing types: expanding_count Number of non-null observations expanding_sum Sum of values expanding_mean Mean of values expanding_median Arithmetic median of values expanding_min Minimum expanding_max Maximum expandingg_std Unbiased standard deviation expanding_var Unbiased variance expanding_skew Unbiased skewness (3rd moment) expanding_kurt Unbiased kurtosis (4th moment)

plot_index(data, name='Index', nb=True, datarange=None, xticks=10, xticks_fontsize=10, dateformat=False, figsize=(10, 8), xmargin=True, ymargin=True, legend=True, smoother=None, output=None, dpi=300, grid=True, xlabel='Year', ylabel='', title='', win_size=10, win_type='boxcar', center=False, std=0.1, beta=0.1, power=1, width=1, min_periods=None, freq=None, scategory=None, frac=0.3333333333333333, it=3, figsave=None)[source]¶

Function to plot the Climate Forcing indicator for the ESR 2013, it follow graphic guidlines from the past ESR adding functionalities like : several kind of smoothline with different

Parameters:
  • data – pandas dataframe - input data
  • name – string - name used as dataframe index
  • nb – bolean if True the function is optimized to render the png inside a notebook
  • datarange – list of 2 integer for mak min year
  • xticks – integer xtick spacing default=10
  • xticks_fontsize – integer xticks fontsize default=10
  • dateformat – boolean if True set the xticks labels in date format
  • figsize – tuple figure size default (10, 8)
  • xmargin – bolean default True
  • ymargin – bolean default True
  • legend – bolean default True
  • smoother – tuple (f,i)
  • output – directory where to save output default None
  • dpi – integer
  • grid – bolean default True
  • xlabel – string default ‘Year’
  • ylabel – string default ‘’
  • title – string default ‘’
  • win_size – integer default 10
  • win_type – string default ‘boxcar’
  • center – bolean default False
  • std – float default 0.1
  • beta – float default 0.1
  • power – integer default 1
  • width – integer default 1
  • min_periods – None
  • freq – None
  • scategory (str) – default ‘rolling’
  • frac (float) – default 0.6666666666666666 Between 0 and 1. The fraction of the data used when estimating each y-value.,
  • it (int) – default 3 The number of residual-based reweightings to perform.
rolling_smoother(data, stype='rolling_mean', win_size=10, win_type='boxcar', center=False, std=0.1, beta=0.1, power=1, width=1)[source]¶

Perform a espanding smooting on the data for a complete help refer to http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/dev/computation.html

Parameters:
  • data –
  • stype –
  • win_size –
  • win_type –
  • center –
  • std –
  • beta –
  • power –
  • width –
Moothing types:
ROLLING :

rolling_count Number of non-null observations rolling_sum Sum of values rolling_mean Mean of values rolling_median Arithmetic median of values rolling_min Minimum rolling_max Maximum rolling_std Unbiased standard deviation rolling_var Unbiased variance rolling_skew Unbiased skewness (3rd moment) rolling_kurt Unbiased kurtosis (4th moment) rolling_window Moving window function

window types:

boxcar triang blackman hamming bartlett parzen bohman blackmanharris nuttall barthann kaiser (needs beta) gaussian (needs std) general_gaussian (needs power, width) slepian (needs width)

gistit(filename, jist='/usr/local/bin/jist', type='notebook')[source]¶

use the jist utility to paste a txt file on github as gist and return a link to it

>>> gistit(notebookfile)
Parameters:
  • filename (str) – path to the a text file or notebook file (.json)
  • jist (str) – path to the executable jist (default=/usr/local/bin/jist)
  • type (str) – notebook, text
Returns:

link to gist if type=text, link to nbviewer if type=notebook
Return type:

str

  • notebookdir –
uploadfile(username='epi', password='epi', hostname='localhost', port=22, inputfile=None, outputfile=None, link=False, apacheroot='/var/www/', zip=False, qr=False)[source]¶

Utility function to upload file on remote server using sftp protocol

>>> uploadfile(inputfile, outputfile)
Parameters:
  • username (str) – username on remote server
  • password (str) – password to access remote server
  • hostname (str) – hostname of remote server (default: localhost)
  • port (int) – port number on remote server (default: 22)
  • inputfile (str) – local path to the file to uploaded
  • outputfile (str) – remote path to the file to upload
  • link (str) – bolean [True, False] default False, print a link to download the file (remote path needs to be in a web available directory)
  • apacheroot (str) – path to apache root default to ‘/var/www/’ required if link == True
  • zip (str) – deafault False, zip the output
  • qr (str) – deafault False, return qrcode as image
Returns:

link to uploaded file if link=True or qr image if qr=True & link=True, none if link is set to false
Return type:

str
which(program)[source]¶

Check if a program exist and return the full path

Parameters:program (str) – executable name or path to executable
Returns:full path to executable
Return type:str
zipdir(basedir, archivename, rm='no')[source]¶

Utility function to zip a single file or a directory

>>> zipdir(input, output)
Parameters:
  • basedir – input file or directory
  • archivename – output file.zip
  • rm – [yes, no], remove source file (optional, default=no)
